I'm from NYC and this was one of the most delicious restaurants I've ever been to! My girlfriend and I loved the meal so much, we even stopped for one more meal at the airport while we were going home. The waiters were very knowledgeable about the food and allergies.

This place has amazing food. The flavors are very developed on each dish.

Ceviche Trio - 3 distinctive flavors. All delicious and a lot of food.  5/5

Tamale - No filling which was strange, but still very good. 3.5/5

Tortilla Soup - They have been making this for 31 years. Unreal flavor. Must try. 5/5

Shrimp w/ Mole - The mole tasted more like salsa but the shrimp has a nice wood fire flavor. 4/5

Oaxacan Steak -  Excellent ribeye and large portion. 4.5/5

I was expecting too much I think. The service was prompt and friendly. But, the moment we had the guacamole, I knew this wasn't going to be an out of the world experience. We left after having a tiny glass of margarita and that bland guacamole. Overpriced and overrated.

The habanero black angus flank steak was dry and had little flavor.  I would recommend a different dish.  The side of corn masa with a white cheese was interesting and good.  My wife and I enjoyed the ceviche trio.  The clear winners were the grilled roasted elote corn, along with the peanuts everyone gets.  The spice mixture on those two were awesome.

Service was above average.

Is that Really your policy that working folks in UNIFORM may not sit in the airport restaurant to enjoy their purchase??? It's okay if a uniformed worker such as a police officer or flight crew PURCHASE something from you- they just can't EAT it there -am I clear? Or just I just witness one of your employees make up their own rules and ask folks to leave your establishment?? Wrong on all levels- shame!!!

Food:  Amazing
Drinks:  Great
Service:  Solid

Reservations are a must; this place gets hopping (well done Mr. Bayliss).  Great Mexican ambiance with helpful and knowledgable staff.   We tried four apps, drinks and shared one entree.  All of the food was excellent.  Our waiter recommended a tequlia and helped this gringo understand why and how to drink it.

If you're in River North (or near there) visit Frontera.

Frontera Grill came recommended to me by a friend. And I mean, he reeaallllyyy hyped it up. Boy, did it live up to the hype and then some. Super groovy ambiance and absolutely delicious food. Our table ordered the Oaxacan Carne Asada, the Flautas Picantes and the Ceviche Trio. NONE of us left disappointed. My carne asada was off-the-charts delicious and my wife loved the flautas appetizer that she ordered as her entree. The one thing I missed though, was the standard chips and salsa that you can usually snack on at most mexican joints. There were none! That was a bummer, but the delicious, high-quality food made up for it. I can't wait to come back.

I went here for lunch during restaurant week.  I ordered the ceviche, tacos, and flan.

The ceviche was amazing and very fresh.  The pork tacos were very good.  They make their own corn tortillas which are very good.  The flan was a lighter flan than usual that was topped with mango and other fruit.

Overall, it was a very good lunch for the price I paid

I'm not a fan of real authentic Mexican (get me a Chipotle or Chevy's any day) just because I think chocolate moles are weird. But this place was much better than I expected and had some surprises.

For my cocktail I ordered a Mora Menta. It tasted like tequila and soda mixed in with fruit juice and chilis. Although different, it wasn't that bad. The guacamole is really good here. I couldn't get enough of it.

We also ordered a tuna salsa - although good, avoid that if you have to. It cost $16 and barely a few teaspoons of tuna buried at the bottom.

My main course was the Friday special which was a slow braised beef. It was very tender and came with a mole sauce of chilis and chocolate. I though it was going to be bitter and spicy, but the taste was actually quite mild.

I enjoyed my dinner here.  My partner and I shared the classic ceviche, the classic guacamole, and my main was the pork in veracruz red mole sauce.

Of all the dishes, the ceviche was not that impressive.  The pieces of the tuna were small and the flavor not that great.   The guacamole was very good thought. I enjoyed the simplicity of the dish and the flavors of the avocado.

The pork in red mole was excellent.   The flavors of the red mole was very savory.   It help kick up the flavor of the pork in a good way. The pork was served tender and moist. This was a very good dish.

I found the service to be very attentive. The wait staff was always refilling our water and cleaning the tables after cleaning the plates.

I am happy to have visited and will visit again when I return back to Chicago.

Wonderful options for vegetarians. And not fried beans. :)
Had the tastiest tacos I have ever eaten on corn tortillas here. My guy and I decided to get the portabella on corn tacos, with black beans and guac, with a side of asparagus in a chocolate mole sauce and squash and onions in a cream sauce. All of the veggies together in the tacos was an explosion of spicy, sweet and so flavorful, it kept me eating more and more tacos, more than planned. I struggle often with eating vegetarian and this place made me absolutely love eating Mexican. Well done Rick Bayless.

Totally struggled with this review because I generally am a fan of Bayless and all things in his empire, but while lunch here was fine, this probably won't be on the list for a return trip...

Had the shredded beef enchiladas and seafood tostada...
Enchilada had good depth but some sweetness to it that I didn't really care for, and not enough sauce/cheese that my little Texas heart was craving
The tostada was more tart than flavorful, enough so that the third tostada wasn't touched... Although fresh enough that I would pick at it...

I thought dessert (tres leches) would be chocolate overload but was had less chocolatey flavor than expected...

Service was fine (friendly if a little inattentive) and the salsas were authentic....

La Vista, above Frontera Grill, was the perfect setting for my daughter's intimate wedding last night.  The guacamole cart, ceviche, tacos made to order (with tacos being pressed real time), fresh churros and chocolate pecan bites were better than you can imagine.  And the Topolo Margaritas are the best you will ever have.  

The room was gorgeous and the music and ambience just right.

Thank you Dana and Raymond for planning and executing a perfect event for my family!

My friends and I dined here earlier this evening. The food and wait staff were fantastic, but the reason for my rating was the rude behavior demonstrated by the woman working the valet desk. Her attitude was beyond repulsive and it was uncalled for. She accosted my friend by putting her finger in my friend's  face and she lied about what time the restaurant closed simply so she could leave early. Granted she doesn't work for Frontera Grill, but she is affiliated with them so therefore she does represent the restaurant and is doing them a terrible disservice.
Food was amazing! Service impeccable. Very reasonably priced. We were pleasantly surprised! Would definitely eat again!!

Yes, yes, holy hell yes! First night in Chicago my friend and I are walking the street to head to a bar and she spots Frontera. She tells me that it's famous and we should've planned ahead to eat there. I check online to see if there's any reservation available, and there's a spot in an hour! It couldn't have been more perfect. When we arrived we spent a long while determining which route to go for dinner and ended up with:

The Oyster/ Ceviche Half Platter: Do it. Absolutely do it. It's a good sized portion, with amazing flavors and super fresh seafood.

Smoked Chicken Queso: It's the chef's recommendation for a reason! Trust! It also comes with corn tortillas (so warm and delicious) as well as chips.

I had to make reservation months in advance. There was 6 of us so I understand that is never easy when dining with a bigger group at a very popular restaurant. Sometimes it is crazy to me to think this place has been around for so long and still before opening this place has a line out the door.

This past Saturday my family and I went to Aladdin and then had reservations at 6PM for 6 people. We got out of the play early and thought maybe they could take us early. There was a line out the door before opening at 5PM. We decided to grab a drink at bottlefork which is just next door. At 5:40, we walked next door to Frontera and walked in to a packed Frontera lobby/bar area. I walked up to the host stand and was welcomed by polite staff and escorted to our table.

We sat in the basement which is a lot different than the upstairs. I prefer the downstairs, more quiet, not as chaotic, a little chillier but personal opinion a better experience than the craziness that is upstairs. Some people want that energy but I liked the subdued basement. Our waiter was pleasant and refilled water/soda glasses, and got our drinks promptly, as the rest of our food. Here is what we ordered:

Starter:
-Basic Guacamole- delightful comes with a handful of chips, bowl of guacamole, and two salsas. I could of ate the whole thing myself, but best served for about two people

Entrees:
-Cauliflower Steak- Take a cauliflower slice in half and roast it. Top with black beans. It was a lovely somewhat healthy dish
-Pork Tacos- good, basic
-Pork Enchiladas- good, basic
-Smoked Chicken with the skin with sweet corn sauce- chicken is sliced and served over a sweet corn heavenly sauce, mashed potatoes and green beans. Super good if you like chicken and cream sauces.
-Carne Asada Brava- really good, thinly sliced steak, and the tamales that come with it are amazing

Sides:
-Mash Potatoes-thick creamy heaven
-Fried Sweet Plantains- topped with crema which was subtle and amazing
-Traditional Black Beans- Frontera's black beans are my favorite black beans ever. Thick, served in a mini cast iron skillet. sooo good.

Dessert:
Mexican Chocolate Ice Cream with a side of Chocolate Sauce- good for one to two people. Chocolate creamy ice cream. With a silky side of chocolate
Mexican Vanilla Ice Cream- tasted more like sorbet than ice cream. Sweeter and light. It was good.

Having been to Xoco last time we were in Chicago, this time we opted for Rick Bayless' James Beard awarded restaurant Frontera Grill. As I was in a soup mood, we shared their famous tortilla soup ($9) and the carnes al carbon para tacos ($20).

The soup was a dark broth with pasilla, grilled chicken, avocado, artisan Jack cheese, homemade crema, and crispy tortilla strips. It was hearty and delicious - the perfect soup for whether you're cold or just need a warm hug inside.

We opted for the skirt steak tacos, but our server made a mistake and brought us portobello mushrooms at first. He was nice enough to comp us for the mushrooms, and we ended up having both the steak and mushroom tacos for the price of one. The steak was marinated with garlic and a variety of spices, while the mushrooms were marinated with garlic, agave nectar, and spices. Both were delicious and packed with flavor. I wasn't even that hungry, but the tacos made me eager for more.

For less than $40, we had a very satisfying meal at Frontera Grill. We would absolutely come back here (or any of Rick Bayless' restaurants to be frank). There are a lot more options on the menu that we haven't tried, and we'll just have to come back to Chicago soon to get our Bayless Mexican fill.

Holy crap! This is the best Mexican food I've ever had (and I've had real Mexican food in Mexico, as well as having a ton of great options here in Phoenix). I just can't say enough about the quality of the food here, all the way from the chips and salsa to the post-meal coffee.

I started with chips, salsa, and guacamole. Chips - super fresh, tasty, and crisp. Salsa - amazing flavor, and it was so well prepared, not watery like most restaurants. The guacamole was better than mine! Perfect mix of chunky and creamy; great heat; and the ingredients just like I like it. Best guac anywhere.

For the entree, I had the enchiladas. Now, I'm a vegetarian, so I asked for them with no meat. You get three enchiladas and black beans. Even the black beans were freaking gourmet awesomeness. The enchiladas -- just wow. I'm really picky about enchiladas. From the tortillas to the meltiness of the cheese, to all the flavors that go into it, I have massive expectations for a simple enchilada. And this place -- just wow.  Best, most flavorful combination of cheeses and incredible sauce. Can't say enough about it.

I finished with a cappuccino, no really expecting much. This cup of coffee tasted like I was sitting right in the middle of a rain forest. Holy cow.

If you're in Chicago, you gotta put this place on the agenda, no matter how long the wait is.

I'm obsessed with Rick Bayless, so this is a stop in Chicago every time I'm there.

I always order some kind of braised meat. They bring you out homemade corn tortillas and some sauces, and you can just make your own tacos, or eat some meat without a tortilla. It's a joy of a meal. The tequila drinks are always spot on.

If you go on the later side (maybe 30 minutes before closing), you can usually get a few seats at the bar. It's a perfect place.

Simply put: this is the best Mexican food I've ever had, even better than I've had in Mexico. And this was just at brunch - I cant even imagine dinner here.

My wife and I each started with a Chupacabra, which was essentially a Mexican Bloody Mary and some guac. Both were awesome ways to kick off the meal. The guacamole also came with some roja and verde salsa, which also packed a lot of bold flavors.

For entrees we split the Mole Enchiladas and the Enifrijoladas, which knocked our socks off. The mole was uber rich and as authentic as could be. There were so many rich flavors, that the side of beans actually helped cut the intensity haha. The enifijoladas were equally as impressive, with intense flavor (and spice) from the chorizo, balanced by the crema, black bean sauce, and sweet plantains, which put the dish over the top.
